_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  BUCKSHOT TREATING FACILITY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES [§ 68.155(a)]
The Buckshot Treating Facility has a commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside emergency response agencies.

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED [§ 68.155(b)]
The Buckshot Treating Facility, located near Douglas, Wyoming in Converse County, is designed to remove carbon dioxide (CO2) gas from a natural gas blend of coal bed methane and processed conventional gas. The natural gas product throughout the facility is a mixture of flammable gases which are RMP-regulated substances, listed below, at or above the EPA RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.
1. Methane
2. Ethane
3. Propane

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM [§ 68.155(c)]
Employee Participation 
The Buckshot Treating Facility requires employees to participate in all facets of process management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the facilitys accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees are involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is part of the PSM program. These include the development of standardized operating procedures, incident investigation, managemen

t of change, safe work practices, and participation in document reviews. In addition, the PSM program requires that process and employee safety issues are addressed as part of normal operations. 

Process Safety Information
The Buckshot Treating Facility keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These technical documents address the following:
1. Chemical properties and associated hazards
2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process
3. Maximum intended inventories
4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment
5. Equipment design basis and configuration information
6. Identification of all necessary regulatory equipment design documents
7. Sufficient information to ensure Good Engineering Practices
8. Written work procedures with consequences of deviation in them
All the technical documents referenced above are listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM Manual/Files at the facility.
Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDS) which are kept on site at the facility for all employees to read. For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process controls, written procedures, monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.
The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings. This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well

as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to safety features in the process to ensure they are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 
The Buckshot Treating Facility has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazards associated with the PSM covered process. This program systematically examines potential hazards and puts controls in place to manage hazards. The PHAs conducted included HAZOPS and What If Checklists methodologies and included a team of employees who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise. The team is tasked to identify, evaluate and make recommendations in the management of the potential hazards associated with the process. If possible, the team affects the changes necessary to mitigate the hazards identified. If the mitigation required is more involved or cannot be mitigated by the team, their findings are forwarded to management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.
The facility periodically updates and revalidates the PHA to ensure that the hazards identified have been properly mitigated and that new hazards or previously unknown hazards can be dealt with. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five (5) years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer in operation. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

Operating Procedures
The Buckshot Treating Facility maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practices, and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by employees and management. The proc

edures are maintained current and accurate, revising them as necessary by employee's suggestion, compliance audit, PHA's, Good Engineering Practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and Management of Change. Covered process Operating Procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and maintain the covered process unit operating within its safe limits.

Safe Work Practices
The Buckshot Treating Facility has developed and implemented safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, Industrial Standards, and Good Engineering Practices to provide the control of hazards and to ensure the safety of employees and the public.

Training
The Buckshot Treating Facility has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating the covered process. New employees receive basic training in process operations at this facility. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review and written test specific to the facility operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the Operating Procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted at least every three (3) years, or more frequently upon request or need. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

Contractors
The Buckshot Treating Facility uses Contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some Contractors work on or near covered process equi

pment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that Contractors:
1. Perform their work in a safe manner
2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills to perform the necessary tasks
3. Are aware of the hazards in the workplace - both the ones they bring to the worksite and the ones that exist at the facility
4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency
5. Understand and follow site safety rules
6. Inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work
7. Know and understand the "Stop Work" policy at the facility
This is accomplished by providing Contractors with:
1. A process overview of the facility
2. Information about safety and health hazards found at the facility
3. Emergency response plan requirements
4. Safe work practices and requirements before beginning work
In addition, the Buckshot Treating Facility will evaluate the Contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a Contractor. Facility personnel periodically monitor Contractor performance regarding their safety obligations.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
The Buckshot Treating Facility conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the Process Safety Information or procedure. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and services as quality assurance verification that the Chemical Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
The Buckshot Treating Facility has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating, pressure containing and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program includ

e, but are not limited to, the following:
1. Conducting training
2. Developing written procedures
3. Performing inspections and tests
4. Correcting identified deficiencies
5. Applying quality assurance measures
Personnel involved in maintaining the on-going integrity of process equipment Maintenance personnel receive training on:
1. Overview of the process
2. Safety and Health hazards
3. Applicable maintenance procedures based on manufacturer's recommendations and operational experience
4. Emergency Response Plan
5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner
Written procedures provide that work is performed in a consistent manner and serve as a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is operating within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. A Management of Change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.
An integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance. Buckshot Treating Facility incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to ensure new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Management Of Change (MOC)
The Buckshot Treating Facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all reported covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.
Changes are reviewed to:
1. Ensure changes do not introduce unknown hazards to the process 
2. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards
3. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a prop

osed change
Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. All operations and maintenance personnel are appropriately trained on changes prior to being implemented or before affected personnel are expected to perform duties on equipment or processes relevant to the change.

Incident Investigation
The Buckshot Treating Facility promptly investigates all incidents related to a covered process that result in or could reasonably result in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personnel injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause(s) and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least five (5) years.

Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Buckshot Treating Facility conducts compliance audits at least every three (3) years to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Facility and support personnel, including operations, maintenance, engineering and HSE, participate in the audits. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS [§ 68.155(c)]
The following existing saf

ety features are applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.
Universal Prevention Activities
The Buckshot Treating Facility accident prevention program and response procedures are applied to all RMP-covered processes. Collectively, these prevention program activities help to prevent or mitigate potential release scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and/or human error.
Specialized Safety Features
Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:
1. Quickly detect a release;
2. Contain/control a release, and;
3. Reduce the consequences of a release of an RMP regulated substance
The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:
Release Detection
1. Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
2. Hydrogen Sulfide detectors with alarms
Release Containment/Control
1. Process equipment pressure relief valves 
2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
3. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high or low pressure, temperature, etc.) 
4. Automated facility shutdown system to shut down engines, utilities, and operate automated valves to fail-safe positions
5. Curbing, diking, containments, and/or berms to contain liquid releases
6. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, safety switches, etc.)
Release Mitigation
1. Personnel trained for incidental release control and incipient stage fires
2. Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3. Portable fire extinguishers

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY [§ 68.155(d)]
Buckshot Treating Facility has had zero RMP-regulated substance releases during the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM [§ 68.155(e)]
The Buckshot Treating Facility is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan, which was developed in accordance
